title: Ciaran Carson, Belfast-born poet deeply immersed in Irish music whose work approached the Troubles with ‘a kind of edited surreality’ – obituary
text:
​Ciaran Carson, who has died of cancer aged 70, was a poet whose work captured the sense of strangeness that comes from living in Belfast and the world.

His digressive and erudite poems, as well as his unpredictable prose, can often put imaginary places and situations alongside real ones, and dream sequences are a regular feature of his oeuvre. In “Turn Again”, for example, he writes of “the streets that never existed”, and then lists them.

One collection, The Twelfth of Never (1999), is an opioid reverie whose 77 sonnets combine images of Japan, ancient Greece and contemporary Ireland, giving equal prominence to poppies and potatoes.
